BRITISH BSSIBHHCY AND CONSULATE GENERAL, BUSHIHE. Dated 26th January, 1945. i * J3 ii (*li *1 * % -w v... . No_ J I am now taking up the question of furniture and. office equipment for the Political Resident's new office “building at Bahrain. 2. Croning tells me your office has very good office furniture and I should he most grateful if you could have the articles detailed in the enclosed list made for the office. We are endeavouring to obtain other furniture elsewhere. 3. In anticipation of your being able to assist I enclose a draft for Rs. 1,000/- towards the cost of the furniture. I should be very glad if you could have work started immediately and if you would send me an estimate showing the total cost of all items. It would simplify our budget if you could have a separate account maintained for the furniture. 1 Major T. Hickinbotham, C.I.E., O.B.E., Political Agent, Bahrain . 4List of furniture for the Political Resident's new office 'building at Bahrain. (a) 4 strong plain dealwood writing tables without drawers for clerics. Surface of each table to be 4^' x 3' and all tables to be of exactly the same height so that they can be placed together if necessary. (b) 2 strong plain dealwood typing tables without drawers. Surface of each table to be of the same size and design as the typing tables in the Agency office. (c) 8 armless office chairs for clerks. The seats to be made of cane if possible but if cane is-not available 3 plywood. See sketch) (d) 1 knee hole teak wood desk for the Political Resident. The surface of the table to be 6* x 3' 4”. The surface except for a border of wood to be covered with dark blue cloth. The desk to have 3 drawers on either side of the knee hole. (e) 2 plain teak wood writing tables for the Secretary and Assistant Secretary of the same size and design as the table hitherto lent to the Political Resident when on tour in Bahrain. (f) 3 teak wood and 4 dealwood file racks each rack to have 3 shelves. Height 3'6 M and length 3'6'. (g) 6 teak wood and 4 dealwood file trays. (h) 6 teak wood stationery racks to hold foolscap, writing paper envelopes, slips, etc. (for placing on writing tables). (i) 3 good wooden waste-paper-baskets (for Political Resident, Secretary and Assistant Secretary) and 3 dealwood waste-paper- baskets for clerks. (j) 2 strong dealwood benches (each to seat 3 persons) for farrashes. A '*y (k) One buff coloured carpet 13'6” x 13'6” similar to that in Political Agent, Bahrain's upstairs office. The only alternative appears to be to try Karachi where you would get better furniture and probably much cheaper even including freight. 3. Bangalore carpets in a plain fawn colour can be ft obtained from the All India Agency, 20 St. Mark^ Road, Bangalore at Rs.4/8/- per square yard. My dear Belgrave, Would you very kindly lend us a fire engine for a few hours? The water is leaking out of the garden tube well into the foundation of the Resident’s office and I understand no progress can be made unless we pump the water out. Fhe 29th of December, 1945 My dear pelly, The two gaps in the Agency compound wall caused by the erection of the Resident*s Building are causing me considerable concern, and I have been asking Mr. Qadri, the Overseer, to make gates to close them for the last two months. He always has some reason for not complying. 2. Possibly his reasons are good but, in my opinion, the needs of security over-ride them. As an instance you should know that three drunken Americans raided the Agency a few nights ago but were caught by the British Police before they did any mischief. 3. I consider the matter to be urgent but I cannot get anything done here. As the matter is one connected with the Residents Building I should be grateful, if the Resident has no objection, if you could get orders sent to the overseer to take the work of closing the gaps in hand immediately. Yours sincerely C. J. Pelly, K X S4* j O.B.k., X.C.S., Secretary to the Honourable the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, B u s h i r e. NS» IMPORTANT HINTS Steel & Water DON'T spatter water on Steel Furniture when washing floors, or otherwise, or let v-moisture remain on it. Wipe it gently with soft cloth. We recommend placing otrawboard on the tops of those articles which cannot be easily wuped. DON’T expose Steel Furniture (especially Safes) to rain-water while in transit. Cover it up with tarpaulin or water-proof paper. DON’T clean Steel Furniture with water. Use motor-car polish instead; we reco mmend polishing with ‘Simoniz’ and cheese-cloth DON’T paste paper-labels on Steel Furniture, because gum or paste has water in it. Paint letters instead; or preferably affix our label-holder or (engraved) name-plate, Keys packed inside the article; to open, safes, cupboards, turn the bolt-handle. DON T keep the duplicate key in the article itself. Give it in a sealed cover to your bankers instead. DON’T forget to note down the number on the key. You will need to send it for our reference, should you lose the key. DON’T keep the No. 1 and No. 2 Keys of your Godrej Safe in the same bunch; because if you lose one, you lose the other, and the Safe could then be opened in your absence. Remember that the No. 2 key is a check-key which comes in handy when the No. 1 key is lost; also it can be used for keeping your Safe in joint- custody. Unpacking Articles should only be unpacked after they are taken to site. Levelling For smooth working of the doors, your Safe or Cupbord should be placed in perfect level, before using it. by stuffing paper packing if and where required. P. T. O.Safes Oil the pivots, chiefly the upper one, every month or so. Over the unber'hn there is a hole for oiling. Pper l u * Filing-Cabinets—The grooves of the Slide fixed to the drawer should he well oilec or greased. Looks-Locks should not be oiled, as oil will only clog the lock-mechanism. Damage in Transit Before despatching from the factory, all articles are carefully examined and securely pac -e j expert packers; and, in order to avoid damage, all articles are loaded in Bombay by our own trained men. But goods are liable to be damaged when they are runs upped the way and/or when unloaded at destination, due to their being rouu down bodily from the railway wagon. We request you, therefore, to instruct our muccadam or the station-master to see that the unloading is done carefully Likewise, care should he taken to ensure safe removal to site. ' As every care is taken by us when despatching, we do not accept any liability for damage inflicted in transit. Ior GODREJ& BOYCE MFC. CO.. LTD. This Policy covers:— (a) the risks excluded from the Standard Form of English Marine Policy by the clause:— ‘Warranted free of capture, seizure, arrest, restraint or detainment, and the consequences thereof or of any attempt thereat; also from the consequences of hostilities or warlike operations, whether there be a declaration of war or not; but this warranty shall not exclude collision, contact with any fixed or floating object (other than a mine or torpedo), standing, heavy weather or tire unless caused directly (and independently of the nature of the voyage or service which the vessel concerned or, in the case of a collision, any other vessel involved therein, is performing) by a hostile act by or against a belligerent power; and for the purpose of this warranty ‘power’ includes any authority maintaining naval, military or air forces in association with a power. Further warranted free from the consequences of civil war, revolution, rebellion, insurrection, or civil strife arising therefrom or piracy.” (b) loss of or damage to the interest hereby insured caused by:— (1) hostilities, warlike operations, civil war, revolution, rebellion, insurrection or civil strife arising therefrom ( 2 ) mines, tropedOes, bombs or other engines of war but excluding loss or damage covered by the Standard Form of English Marine Policy with the Free of Capture &c Clause (as quoted in I (a)*) inserted therein. 2. Notwithstanding the provisions of Clause I, this policy is warranted free of any claim based upon loss of or frustration of, the insured voyage or adventure caused by arrests restraints or detainments of Kings Princes Peoples Usurpers or persons attempting to usurp power. 3. This insurance covers the interest hereby insured during :— (i) transit by craft to or from the vessel. (ii) deviation, delay, forced discharge, re-shipment and transhipment. (iii) any other variation of the adventure arising from the exercise of a liberty granted to the shipowner or charterer under the contract of affreightment. 6. In the event of the interest hereby insured being discharged at a port or place other than the destination named herein, in circumstances beyond the control of the Assured, the insurance continues until the interest is sold and delivered at such port or place; or, if the interest be not sold but forwarded by vessel or craft to the destination named herein or to any other destination, the insurance continues until the vessel or craft arrives at the original or substituted final port or place of discharge and thereafter as provided in Clause 3. 7. Held covered at a premium to be arranged in case of change of voyage or of any omission or error in the description of the interest, vessel or voyage. 8. Warranted free of loss or damage proximately caused by delay, inherent vice or loss of marKet, or of any claim for expenses arising from delay except such expenses as would be recoverable in principle in English law and practice under York-Antwerp Rules 1924 . 9. General average and salvage charges payable (subject to the terms of these clauses) according to Foreign Statement or York-Antwerp Rules if in accordance with the contract of affreightment. 10. Claims for loss or damage within the terms of these clauses shall be oayable without reference to average conditions. 11. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: ‘File 18/16 Construction of new office for Political Resident’s Staff’

physicalDescription.extent: Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 182; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-161; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains papers, mostly correspondence, invoices and insurance certificates, relating to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf’s new office building at Bahrain. It includes papers relating to the following: cement required for the construction of the new office; the shipment of paint, furniture and office equipment for the office; the electric installation of the building; the supply of fans for the office; and a new telephone and line connection being installed in the office.The correspondence is largely between the Political Agent at Bahrain, and the following: HM Consul at Bushire; the Secretary to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf at Bushire; the Executive Engineer, Independent Persian Gulf Sub-Division (also known as the Executive Engineer, British Consulate-General, Bushire); Mackinnon, Mackenzie and Company, Karachi; and the State Engineer, Bahrain.Detailed file notes are found on folios 165 to 181.

name.namePart: Independent Persian Gulf Sub Division, Executive Engineer
